coverage: Full Micah: prophet & superscription; courtroom theophany; capitals and Shephelah puns; corrupt rulers, priests, and prophets; social theft and victims; remnant; messianic shepherd-king from Bethlehem, Breaker, Zion peace vision; exile to Babylon and rescue; enemies (Assyria, nations); historical allusions (Exodus leaders, Balak/Balaam, Omri/Ahab); ethics of 6:8, forgiveness and covenant doxology; rhetorical structure; purge program; reception history.
id_scheme: Cross-book stable by (type+primary-slug) with deterministic hash; alias reuse for shared entities.

entries: The LORD from his holy temple
The LORD comes down, treads high places

entries.name: Micah of Moresheth
entries.blurb: Rural prophet from Moresheth-Gath, speaking bluntly against urban corruption in Samaria and Jerusalem.

entries.name: Moresheth-Gath (hometown)
entries.blurb: Shephelah town in Judah’s southwest; Micah’s rural roots ground his agrarian ethical vision.

entries.name: Jotham of Judah
entries.blurb: First of the kings in Micah’s superscription; period of relative stability before Ahaz.

entries.name: Ahaz of Judah
entries.blurb: Crisis reign marked by Syro-Ephraimite war and Assyrian entanglements; religious compromise proliferates.

entries.name: Hezekiah of Judah
entries.blurb: Reformer king during Assyrian pressure; Micah’s critique shapes later repentance (cf. Jer 26:18).

entries.name: Assyrian era backdrop
entries.blurb: Late 8th century BCE context—imperial tribute, siege warfare, deportations looming over both kingdoms.

entries.name: Contemporaries: Isaiah, Hosea, Amos
entries.blurb: Micah overlaps with other 8th-century prophets; themes echo and spar with Isaiah 2, Hos 4, Am 5.

entries.name: YHWH the Witness-Judge
entries.blurb: God summons creation to hear the covenant case; plaintiff and judge in one.

entries.name: Hear, you peoples—all of you
entries.blurb: Universal summons; the case against Israel educates the nations.

entries.name: Mountains and hills as witnesses
entries.blurb: Ancient, enduring witnesses called to testify to Yahweh’s righteous dealings.

entries.name: Covenant lawsuit (rîb)
entries.blurb: Legal genre frames charges and ethical requirements; justice is covenantal, not merely civic.

entries.name: The LORD from his holy temple
entries.blurb: Judgment emanates from sacred center; holiness does not shield Zion from scrutiny.

entries.name: The LORD comes down, treads high places
entries.blurb: Divine warrior imagery: mountains melt like wax before the presence of the LORD.

entries.name: Mountains melt, valleys split
entries.blurb: Cosmic upheaval as moral earthquake—creation convulses at covenant breach.

entries.name: Samaria (ruin)
entries.blurb: Northern capital to be made a heap in the field; idolatrous wealth smashed and burned.

entries.name: Jerusalem/Zion (corrupt foundations)
entries.blurb: Heads judge for a bribe, priests teach for pay, prophets divine for money—Zion built with blood faces plowing.

entries.name: Gath (‘Tell it not’)
entries.blurb: Echoes David’s lament; news management fails to hide judgment’s shame.

entries.name: Beth-le-aphrah (House of Dust)
entries.blurb: Call to roll in the dust—name becomes enacted lament; Judah’s grief goes to ground.

entries.name: Shaphir (Beautiful)
entries.blurb: The ‘beautiful’ town goes out naked and ashamed; wordplay exposes reversed fortunes.

entries.name: Zaanan (Going Out)
entries.blurb: ‘Going-out’ town cannot go out; siege seals the streets—freedom frozen.

entries.name: Beth-ezel (House of Support)
entries.blurb: Neighbor’s support withdrawn; the house of ‘support’ offers none in crisis.

entries.name: Maroth (Bitterness)
entries.blurb: Waits anxiously for good, but disaster comes from the LORD—bitter providence.

entries.name: Lachish
entries.blurb: War-horse city—first to import northern idolatry into Judah; a relay station of sin.

entries.name: Moresheth-gath (Dowry-town)
entries.blurb: ‘Dowry’ pun: parting gift to heirs—Micah’s home area is handed over.

entries.name: Achzib (Deception)
entries.blurb: ‘Deceptive brook’—promises water but dries up; kings of Israel find it a lie.

entries.name: Mareshah (Conqueror)
entries.blurb: A ‘conqueror’ will indeed come to the ‘Conqueror-town’—poetic justice.

entries.name: Adullam
entries.blurb: Refuge of David now becomes repository of Judah’s glory—exile imagery revived.

entries.name: Heads of Jacob / rulers of Israel
entries.blurb: Cannibal rulers who flay and boil the people—grotesque metaphor for predatory governance.

entries.name: Judges who sell justice
entries.blurb: Verdicts priced; courts become marketplaces—law as luxury good.

entries.name: Priests who teach for a price
entries.blurb: Instruction monetized; sacred vocation becomes side-hustle.

entries.name: Prophets who cry ‘Peace’ when fed
entries.blurb: Stomachs steer sermons; oracles become meal tickets.

entries.name: Night and darkness for seers
entries.blurb: Revelation withdrawn from hireling prophets; shame covers their faces.

entries.name: Build Zion with blood
entries.blurb: Urban splendor erected on violence; architecture as indictment.

entries.name: ‘Is not the LORD among us?’ presumption
entries.blurb: Slogan of invulnerability—misreads covenant presence as talisman.

entries.name: Micah filled with power, justice, might
entries.blurb: True prophet stands in the Spirit to name sin without price tag.

entries.name: Devisers of iniquity at morning’s light
entries.blurb: Insomnia of greed—plotting on pillows, practicing at sunrise.

entries.name: Seizing fields and houses
entries.blurb: Land-grabs undo Jubilee economics—inheritance stolen by pen and power.

entries.name: Evicting women from pleasant houses
entries.blurb: Mothers displaced; domestic security shattered by elites.

entries.name: Children stripped of glory forever
entries.blurb: Intergenerational theft—future clipped by present greed.

entries.name: No one to cast the measuring line by lot
entries.blurb: Assembly rights revoked; dispossessed silenced in land allocation.

entries.name: ‘Do not preach!’ they preach
entries.blurb: Censorship of truth; prophetic gag order from comfortable pews.

entries.name: Merchants with false scales and weights
entries.blurb: Economic fraud sacralized—bags of deceit, stones that cheat.

entries.name: Violence in the houses of the rich
entries.blurb: Palatial neighborhoods built on blood and lies.

entries.name: No cluster to eat—first-ripe fig desired
entries.blurb: Prophet’s harvest lament; righteous vanish like summer fruit.

entries.name: The best of them is like a brier
entries.blurb: Elite likened to thorns—approach means snag and wound.

entries.name: Trust not in neighbor; guard your lips
entries.blurb: Social fabric frays so far that households divide; intimacy becomes risk.

entries.name: Faithful remnant (gathered, healed)
entries.blurb: God assembles the lame and banished; remnant becomes both dew of blessing and lion of judgment.

entries.name: The Breaker goes up before them
entries.blurb: Shepherd-king who opens the gate; people follow; the LORD at their head.

entries.name: Bethlehem Ephrathah—small yet ruler emerges
entries.blurb: From the least comes the greatest; origins ‘from of old’ signal Davidic hope renewed.

entries.name: He shall stand and shepherd in LORD’s strength
entries.blurb: Stability and security flow from messianic shepherding; greatness to the ends of the earth.

entries.name: He shall be our peace
entries.blurb: Messianic identity equated with shalom—personified peace.

entries.name: Seven shepherds and eight leaders
entries.blurb: Enigmatic fullness of leadership raised against Assyria—symbolic abundance of protection.

entries.name: They shepherd Assyria with the sword
entries.blurb: Aggressive defense imagery; enemies’ strongholds subdued.

entries.name: Remnant like dew among nations
entries.blurb: Gentle, heaven-sent refreshment—mission without dependence.

entries.name: Remnant like a lion among flocks
entries.blurb: Strength and inevitability—none can deliver from their hand.

entries.name: Many nations come to Zion
entries.blurb: International pilgrimage for Torah instruction—mission by attraction.

entries.name: Law/Torah goes forth from Zion
entries.blurb: Word from Jerusalem re-orders the world’s ethics.

entries.name: Swords into plowshares
entries.blurb: Disarmament by discipleship; warfare replaced by agrarian labor.

entries.name: Each under vine and fig tree
entries.blurb: Security without militarism; sabbath economy embodied.

entries.name: We will walk in the name of the LORD
entries.blurb: Covenant distinctiveness affirmed amidst pluralism.

entries.name: Gathering the lame and the banished
entries.blurb: God’s preferential option for the broken—kingdom composed of healed exiles.

entries.name: Tower of the flock (Migdal-eder)
entries.blurb: Watchtower image; first dominion restored to daughter Zion—pastoral royalty.

entries.name: Daughter Zion in labor
entries.blurb: Birth pangs before deliverance: exile to Babylon precedes rescue.

entries.name: Exile to Babylon; there you shall be rescued
entries.blurb: Specific exile-rescue horizon—judgment braided with hope.

entries.name: Arise and thresh, daughter Zion
entries.blurb: Horns of iron, hoofs of bronze—sanctified strength to devote spoil to the LORD.

entries.name: Assyria (invader)
entries.blurb: Primary geopolitical threat in Micah’s horizon; foil for messianic peace.

entries.name: Egypt & Assyria restored pathways
entries.blurb: Future highway imagery—diaspora gathered from rival powers.

entries.name: Babylon (named exile)
entries.blurb: City of captivity and stage of promised rescue—intermediate chastening in salvation history.

entries.name: Nations who gloat over Zion
entries.blurb: Coalition of mockers to be shamed; they will lick dust like serpents and fear the LORD.

entries.name: Moses, Aaron, Miriam (Exodus leaders)
entries.blurb: Exodus credentials ground the lawsuit—past grace magnifies present guilt.

entries.name: Balak and Balaam
entries.blurb: Narrative of attempted cursing turned to blessing; remember to know the LORD’s righteous acts.

entries.name: From Shittim to Gilgal
entries.blurb: Journey markers from wilderness to promised land—memory lane as moral argument.

entries.name: Statutes of Omri and works of the house of Ahab
entries.blurb: Northern dynasty paradigms of apostasy imported into Judah; policy becomes idolatry.

entries.name: With what shall I come before the LORD?
entries.blurb: Escalating sacrifices—calves, thousands of rams, rivers of oil, firstborn—exposed as missing the point.

entries.name: Do justice
entries.blurb: Public right-ordering—courts, contracts, care for vulnerable—central to covenant fidelity.

entries.name: Love hesed (covenant loyalty)
entries.blurb: Steadfast love as social glue; mercy beyond reciprocity.

entries.name: Walk humbly with your God
entries.blurb: Posture of dependence and teachability under divine rule.

entries.name: Who is a God like you? (Mi-kah-yah)
entries.blurb: Prophet’s name becomes doxology—God delights in hesed and pardons iniquity.

entries.name: He will tread our iniquities underfoot
entries.blurb: Sin personified and crushed—violence redirected toward evil itself.

entries.name: Cast all our sins into the depths of the sea
entries.blurb: Exodus-colored image of irreversible pardon—no dredging allowed.

entries.name: Light in darkness—bear indignation, He will plead my cause
entries.blurb: Penitential hope: divine advocacy follows discipline; dawn after night.

entries.name: Faithfulness to Jacob, steadfast love to Abraham
entries.blurb: Covenant continuity—promises to patriarchs underwrite restoration.

entries.name: God as shepherd of his people
entries.blurb: Pastoral petition for Bashan and Gilead pastures as in days of old.

entries.name: Dishonest scales and deceitful weights
entries.blurb: Marketplace sins that corrode trust—God weighs the weights.

entries.name: House of the wicked—storehouses of violence
entries.blurb: Supply chains of harm; luxury stocked by oppression.

entries.name: Cannibal metaphor for rulers
entries.blurb: Grotesque image to shock moral senses—people treated as meat.

entries.name: Vineyard and gleaning imagery
entries.blurb: No grapes, no figs—harvest failures mirror moral famine.

entries.name: Vine & fig tree peace ideal
entries.blurb: Domestic abundance and safety—shalom pictured as simple plenty.

entries.name: Micah’s lament—wail like jackals, mourn like ostriches
entries.blurb: Prophet embodies grief; soundscape of judgment.

entries.name: Woe oracles
entries.blurb: Alas-cries announcing doom upon predation and fruitlessness.

entries.name: Judgment–hope alternation (macro-structure)
entries.blurb: Text pulses between threat and promise; pedagogy by oscillation.

entries.name: Parallel with Isaiah 2 (Zion vision)
entries.blurb: Shared oracle of nations streaming; independent witnesses to a common hope.

entries.name: Therefore Zion shall be plowed as a field
entries.blurb: Shock verdict; later cited in Jeremiah as precedent for repentance.

entries.name: Triadic ‘Hear’ oracles
entries.blurb: Summons structure organizes the book’s flow from summons to sentence to solution.

entries.name: Cut off your horses
entries.blurb: Military mobility dismantled—trust relocated to God.

entries.name: Destroy your chariots
entries.blurb: Offensive hardware removed to unlearn war.

entries.name: Tear down your cities
entries.blurb: Urban pride humbled; security decoupled from walls.

entries.name: Throw down all your strongholds
entries.blurb: Fortifications defanged—no more false refuge.

entries.name: Cut off sorceries
entries.blurb: Manipulative spirituality ended; no spellcraft in Zion.

entries.name: No more soothsayers
entries.blurb: Fortune-telling silenced; word of the LORD suffices.

entries.name: Cut off carved images
entries.blurb: Tangible idols removed—art re-purposed to truth.

entries.name: Cut down your pillars
entries.blurb: Cultic steles toppled—memory of false gods erased.

entries.name: Uproot your Asherah poles
entries.blurb: Fertility cult ended at the root; sexuality re-covenanted.

entries.name: Destroy your cities (violence hubs)
entries.blurb: Repeating emphasis: God prunes instruments of oppression.

entries.name: Execute vengeance on nations that did not obey
entries.blurb: Universal moral court—God’s zeal completes the purge.

entries.name: Jeremiah cites Micah (3:12)
entries.blurb: Hezekiah’s generation heeded Micah’s threat—text as precedent for national repentance.

entries.name: Bethlehem prophecy in the Gospels
entries.blurb: Evangelists read Micah 5:2 as pointing to Jesus’ birth at Bethlehem.

entries.name: Micah 6:8 in Jewish and Christian ethics
entries.blurb: Frequently summarized as Torah in miniature; staple of prophetic ethics across traditions.
